Resolved Question Show me another » If hygiene is a concern for McD's play place, why allow your children to play there at all? Ok, the hot discussion right now is to allow your child to run free w/shoes on in McD's play place or not.
Reason to allow it although it is clearly against the rules (sorry, I am big on respecting rules) due to hygienic reservations....I'm going to shoot a hole in this theory:
1. Kids eat w/their hands in this place, primarily a finger food establishment for children 2. Do you glove your children before entering it considering they are touching everything in the place? 2 years ago Report Abuse
Additional Details Just a side note at the mention of high chairs:
This group of mother's actually went to (I think it was) Chuck E. Cheese's and took some samples from the play area and eating areas, particularly high chairs. They took these samples to a lab to be examined and the germs that were lingering was just nasty. In cases like this, ignorance is bliss. 2 years ago On the note of remembering when kids were able to be kids w/o all these rules in regards to safety, do you remember back then that parents weren't sue happy and actually accepted accidents happened. Due to sue happy parents, these rules are there not to protect the children but the establishments themselves. Sad times, folks. 2 years ago Nah, I don't wipe down the highchairs, my kids would be awfully perturbed with me for even considering that one.....they are too old for them...lol 2 years ago by Sookie Member since: 31 January 2010 Total points: 2,758 (Level 4) Add Contact Block

Other Answers (17) Show: All Answers Oldest to Newest Newest to Oldest Rated Highest to Lowest by Tork UK Member since: 23 March 2010 Total points: 143 (Level 1) Add Contact Block Hygiene is particularly important for young children as they have been recognised as being at particular risk of contracting and transmitting enteric (relating to intestines) infection.
This is due to a number of factors:
- They have immature immune systems - They tend to have a higher degress of close contact with other children - They tend to explore with their hands, and germs from hands to mouth can easily cause infections - They share facilities and equipment (as mentioned above) - They may have incomplete immunisations
You can find lots more information of this sort of nature in the Tork online hygiene toolkit - http://bit.ly/9TYNAa
Parents should do their best to set good examples by washing and drying hands properly and frequently and encourage children to do the same! Source(s): www.tork.co.uk 2 years ago Report Abuse by ? Member since: 09 July 2009 Total points: 6,160 (Level 5) Add Contact Block Ewww.
I do not take my kids to McDonald's because I think the food is disgusting so they have never played there. However, we eat at regular restaurants every once in a while and my kids sit in the high chairs. I wash their hands before and after they eat and I also use a disinfectant wipe on the high chair before they sit down. I use my head and I can just imagine what kind of nasty germs are on the tray! I don't want my kids to get unnecessarily sick. I do not keep them in a bubble though. When they play t the playground in our neighborhood, they wear shoes and I don't go around wiping down all the equipment before they touch it. LOL! After the playground, though, they do get a bath but only because they like to play in the dirt. ;P 2 years ago Report Abuse

I am one of those oh so horrible mom's that take their child to the play places (either McD's or BK) on a rainy day or a day when I have a lot of homework to get done (free wifi!!!). We maybe go twice a month and *gasp* we even eat the food! We live in FL and there have been plenty of times that my son was wearing flip flops or crocks and we completely spaced bringing socks so I've even let him run around in there barefoot. He also runs around in the yard barefoot, at the beach, and anywhere else he just happens to take his shoes off. He gets bathed almost every night (we all have our days lol) so at least at the end of the day he is nice and clean before getting into bed! I have never been one to worry about germs and my son is never sick. I also never put one of those cloth shopping cart things on the cart when we went grocery shopping and always used the high chairs at food places if we went out to eat.
I'll probably get thumbed down but it's all good! I have a healthy four year old who actually gets to be a kid! Source(s): Mommy to Caleb, age 4 and 25w4d with baby Molly! 2 years ago Report Abuse

I'm sure this is just another one of those scares that will turn out to be nothing and a few months from now will be completely forgotten about in favor of some new thing we're supposed to be afraid of. 2 years ago Report Abuse
